column2: Chapter III
column3: Chapter three

column2: Until he reached the age of twelve, Georgie's education was a domestic process; tutors came to the house; and those citizens who yearned for his taking down often said: "Just wait till he has to go to public school; then he'll get it!" But at twelve Georgie was sent to a private school in the town, and there came from this small and dependent institution no report, or even rumour, of Georgie's getting anything that he was thought to deserve; therefore the yearning still persisted, though growing gaunt with feeding upon itself.
column3: Until he reached the age of twelve, Georgie's education was a domestic process; tutors came to the house; and those citizens who yearned for his taking down often said: "Just wait till he has to go to public school; then he'll get it!" But at twelve Georgie was sent to a private school in the town, and there came from this small and dependent institution no report, or even rumour, of Georgie's getting anything that he was thought to deserve; therefore the yearning still persisted, though growing gaunt with feeding upon itself.

column2: For, although Georgie's pomposities and impudence in the little school were often almost unbearable, the teachers were fascinated by him.
column3: For, although Georgie's pomposities and impudence in the little school were often almost unbearable, the teachers were fascinated by him.

column2: They did not like him--he was too arrogant for that--but he kept them in such a state of emotion that they thought more about him than they did about all of the other ten pupils.
column3: They did not like him-he was too arrogant for that-but he kept them in such a state of emotion that they thought more about him than they did about all of the other ten pupils.

column2: The emotion he kept them in was usually one resulting from injured self-respect, but sometimes it was dazzled admiration.
column3: The emotion he kept them in was usually one resulting from injured self respect, but sometimes it was dazzled admiration.

column2: So far as their conscientious observation went, he "studied" his lessons sparingly; but sometimes, in class, he flashed an admirable answer, with a comprehension not often shown by the pupils they taught; and he passed his examinations easily.
column3: So far as their conscientious observation went, he "studied" his lessons sparingly; but sometimes, in class, he flashed an admirable answer, with a comprehension not often shown by the pupils they taught; and he passed his examinations easily.

column2: In all, without discernible effort, he acquired at this school some rudiments of a liberal education and learned nothing whatever about himself.
column3: In all, without discernible effort, he acquired at this school some rudiments of a liberal education and learned nothing whatever about himself.

column2: The yearners were still yearning when Georgie, at sixteen, was sent away to a great "Prep School." "Now," they said brightly, "he'll get it! He'll find himself among boys just as important in their home towns as he is, and they'll knock the stuffing out of him when he puts on his airs with them!
column3: The yearners were still yearning when Georgie, at sixteen, was sent away to a great "Prep School." "Now," they said brightly, "he'll get it! He'll find himself among boys just as important in their home towns as he is, and they'll knock the stuffing out of him when he puts on his airs with them!

column2: Oh, but that would be worth something to see!"
column3: Oh, but that would be worth something to see!"

column2: They were mistaken, it appeared, for when Georgie returned, a few months later, he still seemed to have the same stuffing.
column3: They were mistaken, it appeared, for when Georgie returned, a few months later, he still seemed to have the same stuffing.

column2: He had been deported by the authorities, the offense being stated as "insolence and profanity"; in fact, he had given the principal of the school instructions almost identical with those formerly objected to by the Reverend Malloch Smith.
column3: He had been deported by the authorities, the offense being stated as "insolence and profanity"; in fact, he had given the principal of the school instructions almost identical with those formerly objected to by the Reverend Malloch Smith.

column2: But he had not got his come-upance, and those who counted upon it were embittered by his appearance upon the down-town streets driving a dog-cart at criminal speed, making pedestrians retreat from the crossings, and behaving generally as if he "owned the earth." A disgusted hardware dealer of middle age, one of those who hungered for Georgie's downfall, was thus driven back upon the sidewalk to avoid being run over, and so far forgot himself as to make use of the pet street insult of the year: "Got 'ny sense!
column3: But he had not got his come upance, and those who counted upon it were embittered by his appearance upon the down town streets driving a dog cart at criminal speed, making pedestrians retreat from the crossings, and behaving generally as if he "owned the earth." A disgusted hardware dealer of middle age, one of those who hungered for Georgie's downfall, was thus driven back upon the sidewalk to avoid being run over, and so far forgot himself as to make use of the pet street insult of the year: "Got 'n y sense!

column2: See here, bub, does your mother know you're out?"
column3: See here, bub, does your mother know you're out?"

column2: Georgie, without even seeming to look at him, flicked the long lash of his whip dexterously, and a little spurt of dust came from the hardware man's trousers, not far below the waist.
column3: Georgie, without even seeming to look at him, flicked the long lash of his whip dexterously, and a little spurt of dust came from the hardware man's trousers, not far below the waist.

column2: He was not made of hardware: he raved, looking for a missile; then, finding none, commanded himself sufficiently to shout after the rapid dog-cart: "Turn down your pants, you would-be dude!
column3: He was not made of hardware: he raved, looking for a missile; then, finding none, commanded himself sufficiently to shout after the rapid dog cart: "Turn down your pants, you would be dude!

column2: Raining in dear ole Lunnon!
column3: Raining in dear ole Lunnon!

column2: Git off the earth!"
column3: Git off the earth!"

column2: Georgie gave him no encouragement to think that he was heard.
column3: Georgie gave him no encouragement to think that he was heard.

column2: The dog-cart turned the next corner, causing indignation there, likewise, and, having proceeded some distance farther, halted in front of the "Amberson Block"--an old-fashioned four-story brick warren of lawyers offices, insurance and realestate offices, with a "drygoods store" occupying the ground floor.
column3: The dog cart turned the next corner, causing indignation there, likewise, and, having proceeded some distance farther, halted in front of the "Amberson Block"--an old-fashioned four story brick warren of lawyers offices, insurance and realestate offices, with a "drygoods store" occupying the ground floor.

column2: Georgie tied his lathered trotter to a telegraph pole, and stood for a moment looking at the building critically: it seemed shabby, and he thought his grandfather ought to replace it with a fourteen-story skyscraper, or even a higher one, such as he had lately seen in New York--when he stopped there for a few days of recreation and rest on his way home from the bereaved school.
column3: Georgie tied his lathered trotter to a telegraph pole, and stood for a moment looking at the building critically: it seemed shabby, and he thought his grandfather ought to replace it with a fourteen story skyscraper, or even a higher one, such as he had lately seen in New York-when he stopped there for a few days of recreation and rest on his way home from the bereaved school.

column2: About the entryway to the stairs were various tin signs, announcing the occupation and location of upper-floor tenants, and Georgie decided to take some of these with him if he should ever go to college.
column3: About the entryway to the stairs were various tin signs, announcing the occupation and location of upper floor tenants, and Georgie decided to take some of these with him if he should ever go to college.

column2: However, he did not stop to collect them at this time, but climbed the worn stairs--there was no elevator--to the fourth floor, went down a dark corridor, and rapped three times upon a door.
column3: However, he did not stop to collect them at this time, but climbed the worn stairs-there was no elevator-to the fourth floor, went down a dark corridor, and rapped three times upon a door.

column2: It was a mysterious door, its upper half, of opaque glass, bearing no sign to state the business or profession of the occupants within; but overhead, upon the lintel, four letters had been smearingly inscribed, partly with purple ink and partly with a soft lead pencil, "F.
column3: It was a mysterious door, its upper half, of opaque glass, bearing no sign to state the business or profession of the occupants within; but overhead, upon the lintel, four letters had been smearingly inscribed, partly with purple ink and partly with a soft lead pencil, "F.

column2: O. T. A." and upon the plaster wall, above the lintel, there was a drawing dear to male adolescence: a skull and crossbones.
column3: o t a" and upon the plaster wall, above the lintel, there was a drawing dear to male adolescence: a skull and crossbones.

column2: Three raps, similar to Georgie's, sounded from within the room.
column3: Three raps, similar to Georgie's, sounded from within the room.

column2: Georgie then rapped four times the rapper within the room rapped twice, and Georgie rapped seven times.
column3: Georgie then rapped four times the rapper within the room rapped twice, and Georgie rapped seven times.

column2: This ended precautionary measures; and a well-dressed boy of sixteen opened the door; whereupon Georgie entered quickly, and the door was closed behind him.
column3: This ended precautionary measures; and a well dressed boy of sixteen opened the door; whereupon Georgie entered quickly, and the door was closed behind him.

column2: Seven boys of congenial age were seated in a semicircular row of damaged office chairs, facing a platform whereon stood a solemn, red-haired young personage with a table before him.
column3: Seven boys of congenial age were seated in a semicircular row of damaged office chairs, facing a platform whereon stood a solemn, red haired young personage with a table before him.

column2: At one end of the room there was a battered sideboard, and upon it were some empty beer bottles, a tobacco can about two-thirds full, with a web of mold over the surface of the tobacco, a dusty cabinet photograph (not inscribed) of Miss Lillian Russell, several withered old pickles, a caseknife, and a half-petrified section of icing-cake on a sooty plate.
column3: At one end of the room there was a battered sideboard, and upon it were some empty beer bottles, a tobacco can about two thirds full, with a web of mold over the surface of the tobacco, a dusty cabinet photograph (not inscribed) of Miss Lillian Russell, several withered old pickles, a caseknife, and a half petrified section of icing cake on a sooty plate.

column2: At the other end of the room were two rickety card-tables and a stand of bookshelves where were displayed under dust four or five small volumes of M. Guy de Maupassant's stories, "Robinson Crusoe," "Sappho," "Mr.
column3: At the other end of the room were two rickety card tables and a stand of bookshelves where were displayed under dust four or five small volumes of m Guy de Maupassant's stories, "Robinson Crusoe," "Sappho," "mr

column2: Barnes of New York," a work by Giovanni Boccaccio, a Bible, "The Arabian Nights' Entertainment," "Studies of the Human Form Divine," "The Little Minister," and a clutter of monthly magazines and illustrated weeklies of about that crispness one finds in such articles upon a doctor's ante-room table.
column3: Barnes of New York," a work by Giovanni Boccaccio, a Bible, "The Arabian Nights' Entertainment," "Studies of the Human Form Divine," "The Little Minister," and a clutter of monthly magazines and illustrated weeklies of about that crispness one finds in such articles upon a doctor's ante room table.

column2: Upon the wall, above the sideboard, was an old framed lithograph of Miss Della Fox in "Wang"; over the bookshelves there was another lithograph purporting to represent Mr. John L. Sullivan in a boxing costume, and beside it a halftone reproduction of "A Reading From Horner." The final decoration consisted of damaged papiermache--a round shield with two battle-axes and two cross-hilted swords, upon the wall over the little platform where stood the red-haired presiding officer.
column3: Upon the wall, above the sideboard, was an old framed lithograph of Miss Della Fox in "Wang"; over the bookshelves there was another lithograph purporting to represent mr john l Sullivan in a boxing costume, and beside it a halftone reproduction of "A Reading From Horner." The final decoration consisted of damaged papiermache-a round shield with two battle axes and two cross hilted swords, upon the wall over the little platform where stood the red haired presiding officer.

column2: He addressed Georgie in a serious voice:
column3: He addressed Georgie in a serious voice:

column2: Welcome, Friend of the Ace.
column3: Welcome, Friend of the Ace.

column2: Welcome, Friend of the Ace, Georgie responded, and all of the other boys repeated the words, "Welcome, Friend of the Ace."
column3: Welcome, Friend of the Ace, Georgie responded, and all of the other boys repeated the words, "Welcome, Friend of the Ace."

column2: Take your seat in the secret semicircle, said the presiding officer. "We will now proceed to--"
column3: Take your seat in the secret semicircle, said the presiding officer. "We will now proceed to-"

column2: But Georgie was disposed to be informal.
column3: But Georgie was disposed to be informal.

column2: He interrupted, turning to the boy who had admitted him: "Look here, Charlie Johnson, what's Fred Kinney doing in the president's chair?
column3: He interrupted, turning to the boy who had admitted him: "Look here, Charlie Johnson, what's Fred Kinney doing in the president's chair?

column2: That's my place, isn't it? What you men been up to here, anyhow?
column3: That's my place, isn't it? What you men been up to here, anyhow?

column2: Didn't you all agree I was to be president just the same, even if I was away at school?"
column3: Didn't you all agree I was to be president just the same, even if I was away at school?"

column2: Well-- said Charlie Johnson uneasily.
column3: Well- said Charlie Johnson uneasily.

column2: Listen!	Listen!
column3: true

column2: I didn't have much to do with it.
column3: I didn't have much to do with it.

column2: Some of the other members thought that long as you weren't in town or anything, and Fred gave the sideboard, why--"
column3: Some of the other members thought that long as you weren't in town or anything, and Fred gave the sideboard, why-"

column2: Mr. Kinney, presiding, held in his hand, in lieu of a gavel, and considered much more impressive, a Civil War relic known as a "horse-pistol." He rapped loudly for order.
column3: mr Kinney, presiding, held in his hand, in lieu of a gavel, and considered much more impressive, a Civil War relic known as a "horse pistol." He rapped loudly for order.

column2: All Friends of the Ace will take their seats! he said sharply.
column3: All Friends of the Ace will take their seats! he said sharply.

column2: I'm president of the F. O. T. A. now, George Minafer, and don't you forget it!	I'm president of the f o t a now, George Minafer, and don't you forget it!
column3: true

column2: You and Charlie Johnson sit down, because I was elected perfectly fair, and we're goin' to hold a meeting here."
column3: You and Charlie Johnson sit down, because I was elected perfectly fair, and we're goin' to hold a meeting here."

column2: Oh, you are, are you? said George skeptically.
column3: Oh, you are, are you? said George skeptically.

column2: Charlie Johnson thought to mollify him.
column3: Charlie Johnson thought to mollify him.

column2: Well, didn't we call this meeting just especially because you told us to?	Well, didn't we call this meeting just especially because you told us to?
column3: true

column2: You said yourself we ought to have a kind of celebration because you've got back to town, George, and that's what we're here for now, and everything.
column3: You said yourself we ought to have a kind of celebration because you've got back to town, George, and that's what we're here for now, and everything.

column2: What do you care about being president?
column3: What do you care about being president?

column2: All it amounts to is just calling the roll and--"
column3: All it amounts to is just calling the roll and-"

column2: The president de facto hammered the table.
column3: The president de facto hammered the table.

column2: This meeting will now proceed to--
column3: This meeting will now proceed to-

column2: No, it won't, said George, and he advanced to the desk, laughing contemptuously.
column3: No, it won't, said George, and he advanced to the desk, laughing contemptuously.

column2: Get off that platform.
column3: Get off that platform.

column2: This meeting will come to order! Mr. Kinney commanded fiercely.
column3: This meeting will come to order! mr Kinney commanded fiercely.

column2: You put down that gavel, said George.
column3: You put down that gavel, said George.

column2: Whose is it, I'd like to know? It belongs to my grandfather, and you quit hammering it that way or you'll break it, and I'll have to knock your head off.
column3: Whose is it, I'd like to know? It belongs to my grandfather, and you quit hammering it that way or you'll break it, and I'll have to knock your head off.

column2: This meeting will come to order!	This meeting will come to order!
column3: false

column2: I was legally elected here, and I'm not going to be bulldozed!"
column3: I was legally elected here, and I'm not going to be bulldozed!"

column2: All right, said Georgie.
column3: All right, said Georgie.

column2: You're president.	You're president.
column3: false

column2: Now we'll hold another election."
column3: Now we'll hold another election."

column2: We will not! Fred Kinney shouted.
column3: We will not! Fred Kinney shouted.

column2: We'll have our reg'lar meeting, and then we'll play euchre & nickel a corner, what we're here for.	We'll have our reg'lar meeting, and then we'll play euchre and nickel a corner, what we're here for.
column3: true

column2: This meeting will now come to ord--"
column3: This meeting will now come to ord-"

column2: Georgie addressed the members.
column3: Georgie addressed the members.

column2: I'd like to know who got up this thing in the first place, he said.
column3: I'd like to know who got up this thing in the first place, he said.

column2: Who's the founder of the F.O.T.A., if you please?	Who's the founder of the f o t a, if you please?
column3: true

column2: Who got this room rent free?
column3: Who got this room rent free?

column2: Who got the janitor to let us have most of this furniture?
column3: Who got the janitor to let us have most of this furniture?

column2: You suppose you could keep this clubroom a minute if I told my grandfather I didn't want it for a literary club any more?
column3: You suppose you could keep this clubroom a minute if I told my grandfather I didn't want it for a literary club any more?

column2: I'd like to say a word on how you members been acting, too!
column3: I'd like to say a word on how you members been acting, too!

column2: When I went away I said I didn't care if you had a vice-president or something while I was gone, but here I hardly turned my back and you had to go and elect Fred Kinney president!
column3: When I went away I said I didn't care if you had a vice president or something while I was gone, but here I hardly turned my back and you had to go and elect Fred Kinney president!

column2: Well, if that's what you want, you can have it.
column3: Well, if that's what you want, you can have it.

column2: I was going to have a little celebration down here some night pretty soon, and bring some port wine, like we drink at school in our crowd there, and I was going to get my grandfather to give the club an extra room across the hall, and prob'ly I could get my Uncle George to give us his old billiard table, because he's got a new one, and the club could put it in the other room.
column3: I was going to have a little celebration down here some night pretty soon, and bring some port wine, like we drink at school in our crowd there, and I was going to get my grandfather to give the club an extra room across the hall, and prob'ly I could get my Uncle George to give us his old billiard table, because he's got a new one, and the club could put it in the other room.

column2: Well, you got a new president now!" Here Georgie moved toward the door and his tone became plaintive, though undeniably there was disdain beneath his sorrow.
column3: Well, you got a new president now!" Here Georgie moved toward the door and his tone became plaintive, though undeniably there was disdain beneath his sorrow.

column2: I guess all I better do is--resign!
column3: I guess all I better do is-resign!

column2: And he opened the door, apparently intending to withdraw.
column3: And he opened the door, apparently intending to withdraw.

column2: All in favour of having a new election, Charlie Johnson shouted hastily, "say, 'Aye'!"
column3: All in favour of having a new election, Charlie Johnson shouted hastily, "say, 'Aye'!"

column2: Aye was said by everyone present except Mr. Kinney, who began a hot protest, but it was immediately smothered.
column3: Aye was said by everyone present except mr Kinney, who began a hot protest, but it was immediately smothered.

column2: All in favour of me being president instead of Fred Kinney, shouted Georgie, "say 'Aye.' The 'Ayes' have it!"
column3: All in favour of me being president instead of Fred Kinney, shouted Georgie, "say 'Aye.' The 'Ayes' have it!"

column2: I resign, said the red-headed boy, gulping as he descended from the platform.
column3: I resign, said the red headed boy, gulping as he descended from the platform.

column2: I resign from the club!
column3: I resign from the club!

column2: Hot-eyed, he found his hat and departed, jeers echoing after him as he plunged down the corridor.
column3: Hot eyed, he found his hat and departed, jeers echoing after him as he plunged down the corridor.

column2: Georgie stepped upon the platform, and took up the emblem of office.
column3: Georgie stepped upon the platform, and took up the emblem of office.

column2: Ole red-head Fred'll be around next week, said the new chairman. "He'll be around boot-lickin' to get us to take him back in again, but I guess we don't want him: that fellow always was a trouble-maker.
column3: Ole red head Fred'll be around next week, said the new chairman. "He'll be around boot lickin' to get us to take him back in again, but I guess we don't want him: that fellow always was a trouble maker.

column2: We will now proceed with our meeting.
column3: We will now proceed with our meeting.

column2: Well, fellows, I suppose you want to hear from your president.
column3: Well, fellows, I suppose you want to hear from your president.

column2: I don't know that I have much to say, as I have already seen most of you a few times since I got back.
column3: I don't know that I have much to say, as I have already seen most of you a few times since I got back.

column2: I had a good time at the old school, back East, but had a little trouble with the faculty and came on home.
column3: I had a good time at the old school, back East, but had a little trouble with the faculty and came on home.

column2: My family stood by me as well as I could ask, and I expect to stay right here in the old town until whenever I decide to enter college.
column3: My family stood by me as well as I could ask, and I expect to stay right here in the old town until whenever I decide to enter college.

column2: Now, I don't suppose there's any more business before the meeting.
column3: Now, I don't suppose there's any more business before the meeting.

column2: I guess we might as well play cards.
column3: I guess we might as well play cards.

column2: Anybody that's game for a little quarter-limit poker or any limit they say, why I'd like to have 'em sit at the president's card-table."
column3: Anybody that's game for a little quarter limit poker or any limit they say, why I'd like to have 'em sit at the president's card table."

column2: When the diversions of the Friends of the Ace were concluded for that afternoon, Georgie invited his chief supporter, Mr. Charlie Johnson, to drive home with him to dinner, and as they jingled up National Avenue in the dog-cart, Charlie asked:
column3: When the diversions of the Friends of the Ace were concluded for that afternoon, Georgie invited his chief supporter, mr Charlie Johnson, to drive home with him to dinner, and as they jingled up National Avenue in the dog cart, Charlie asked:

column2: What sort of men did you run up against at that school, George?
column3: What sort of men did you run up against at that school, George?

column2: Best crowd there: finest set of men I ever met.
column3: Best crowd there: finest set of men I ever met.

column2: How'd you get in with 'em?
column3: How'd you get in with 'em?

column2: Georgie laughed.
column3: Georgie laughed.

column2: I let them get in with me, Charlie, he said in a tone of gentle explanation.
column3: I let them get in with me, Charlie, he said in a tone of gentle explanation.

column2: It's vulgar to do any other way.	It's vulgar to do any other way.
column3: true

column2: Did I tell you the nickname they gave me--'King'?
column3: Did I tell you the nickname they gave me-'King'?

column2: That was what they called me at that school, 'King Minafer."
column3: That was what they called me at that school, 'King Minafer."

column2: How'd they happen to do that? his friend asked innocently.
column3: How'd they happen to do that? his friend asked innocently.

column2: Oh, different things, George answered lightly.
column3: Oh, different things, George answered lightly.

column2: Of course, any of 'em that came from anywhere out in this part the country knew about the family and all that, and so I suppose it was a good deal on account of--oh, on account of the family and the way I do things, most likely.
column3: Of course, any of 'em that came from anywhere out in this part the country knew about the family and all that, and so I suppose it was a good deal on account of-oh, on account of the family and the way I do things, most likely.

column2: Chapter IV

column2: When Mr. George Amberson Minafer came home for the holidays at Christmastide, in his sophomore year, probably no great change had taken place inside him, but his exterior was visibly altered.
column3: When mr George Amberson Minafer came home for the holidays at Christmastide, in his sophomore year, probably no great change had taken place inside him, but his exterior was visibly altered.

column2: Nothing about him encouraged any hope that he had received his come-upance; on the contrary, the yearners for that stroke of justice must yearn even more itchingly: the gilded youth's manner had become polite, but his politeness was of a kind which democratic people found hard to bear.
column3: Nothing about him encouraged any hope that he had received his come upance; on the contrary, the yearners for that stroke of justice must yearn even more itchingly: the gilded youth's manner had become polite, but his politeness was of a kind which democratic people found hard to bear.

column2: In a word, M. le Due had returned from the gay life of the capital to show himself for a week among the loyal peasants belonging to the old chateau, and their quaint habits and costumes afforded him a mild amusement.
column3: In a word, m le Due had returned from the gay life of the capital to show himself for a week among the loyal peasants belonging to the old chateau, and their quaint habits and costumes afforded him a mild amusement.
